Description: Flat limestone figure rudimentarily carved, certainly representing a horseman. The animal has a large body and a very small head separated from the chest only by a vertical groove, while the neck is only characterised by the curve of its upper contour. Fore legs, thighs and hind legs are broken and lost. The rider is only suggested by a hump in the middle of the back in the shape of a triangle rounded at the top, with pairs of short horizontal notches scored on the front part of the sides.
Curator's comments: W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 71 § 68: "The horseman (fig. 1) was picked up by chance, and the precise locality is unknown; but its similarity to the stone idol (fig.3 [=BM 1906,0301.3]) and the complete absence of Greek objects after the middle of the sixth century. B.C., warrants us in dating it to the seventh century".
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 71 § 68, pl. xxiv, 1)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.44, p.58, p.178, pl.20)
